questions.question: What is an explant in plant tissue culture?
choices: A piece of tissue taken from a parent plant to initiate a culture
A sterilizing agent used in surface sterilization
A specialized container for plant cultures
questions.answer: A piece of tissue taken from a parent plant to initiate a culture

questions.question: Which type of tissue is often preferred for explants due to its high regenerative capacity?
Why are younger tissues generally more responsive in culture than older tissues?
choices: They have a higher proportion of undifferentiated cells
They grow faster in artificial environments
questions.answer: They have a higher proportion of undifferentiated cells

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of surface sterilization in explant preparation?
choices: To remove microorganisms from the surface
To change the plant's genetic makeup
questions.answer: To remove microorganisms from the surface

questions.question: Which of the following is typically used as the main sterilizing agent in surface sterilization?
What is the typical concentration of bleach solution used for surface sterilization?
Why is it important to rinse explants with sterile distilled water after bleach treatment?
choices: To remove traces of the sterilizing agent
To lower the pH of the tissue
questions.answer: To remove traces of the sterilizing agent

questions.question: What is the typical size range for prepared explants?
Which of the following is NOT a factor to consider when selecting an explant?
What is the purpose of using 70% ethanol in the surface sterilization process?
choices: To remove surface contaminants and increase effectiveness of subsequent steps
questions.answer: To remove surface contaminants and increase effectiveness of subsequent steps

questions.question: Which environment is typically used for the final preparation of explants?
What is aseptic technique in the context of explant preparation?
choices: A method to increase plant growth
A way to genetically modify plants
Procedures to maintain sterility and prevent contamination
A technique to induce flowering in culture
questions.answer: Procedures to maintain sterility and prevent contamination

questions.question: Why are meristematic tissues often preferred for explants?
choices: They contain actively dividing cells that are not yet fully differentiated
They are more resistant to disease
questions.answer: They contain actively dividing cells that are not yet fully differentiated

questions.question: What is the first step in the surface sterilization process?

choices: To change the plant's genetic makeup
To speed up the sterilization process

choices: They have a lower water content

questions.question: Why might seasonal changes affect explant selection?
choices: Plants grow faster in certain seasons
Sterilization is more effective in warm weather
The availability and condition of certain tissues may vary with seasons
Culture media work better in specific seasons
questions.answer: The availability and condition of certain tissues may vary with seasons

questions.question: What is the purpose of removing visibly damaged or discolored tissue during explant preparation?
choices: To improve the appearance of the culture
To reduce the risk of contamination and improve culture success
questions.answer: To reduce the risk of contamination and improve culture success

questions.question: Which of the following is a potential alternative sterilization agent to bleach?
Why is it important to minimize the time between cutting the explant and placing it on culture medium?
choices: To prevent the medium from drying out
To reduce the chance of contamination and desiccation
To ensure the explant doesn't grow too large
To maintain the temperature of the explant
questions.answer: To reduce the chance of contamination and desiccation

questions.question: What is the concept of totipotency in relation to explant selection?
choices: The ability of plants to grow in any direction
The capacity of plant cells to regenerate an entire plant
The tendency of explants to become contaminated
The process of plant cell division
questions.answer: The capacity of plant cells to regenerate an entire plant

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a common challenge in explant preparation for wild plant species?
choices: Lack of information on optimal sterilization protocols

questions.question: Why are embryos often easier to sterilize compared to other plant parts?
choices: They are protected within the seed coat
questions.answer: They are protected within the seed coat

questions.question: What is the main disadvantage of using mercuric chloride as a sterilization agent?
choices: It is not effective against bacteria

questions.question: Why might you avoid using underground parts of root crops as explants?
choices: They are more likely to carry soil-borne contaminants
questions.answer: They are more likely to carry soil-borne contaminants

questions.question: What is the primary reason for using nodal segments as explants?
choices: They contain axillary buds with meristematic tissue
They are larger than other explant types
questions.answer: They contain axillary buds with meristematic tissue
